qas.question: What do people typically call a web browser?
What platform is a browser used on?
What does URL mean?
What allows a person to direct their browser to a resource?

plausible_answers.text: a software application for retrieving, presenting, and traversing information resources

qas.question: What is the definition of the World Wide Web?
What helps identify the WWW?

plausible_answers.text: a web page, image, video or other piece of content

qas.question: What are examples of the WWW?

plausible_answers.text: easily to navigate their browsers to related resources

qas.question: What does content present in applications help users do?
What is something that identifies how a video plays in a software application?

paragraphs.context: A web browser (commonly referred to as a browser) is a software application for retrieving, presenting, and traversing information resources on the World Wide Web. An information resource is identified by a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI/URL) and may be a web page, image, video or other piece of content. Hyperlinks present in resources enable users easily to navigate their browsers to related resources.

allenNER.words: A web browser ( commonly referred to as a browser ) is a software application for retrieving , presenting , and traversing information resources on the World Wide Web . An information resource is identified by a Uniform Resource Identifier ( URI / URL ) and may be a web page , image , video or other piece of content . Hyperlinks present in resources enable users easily to navigate their browsers to related resources .

qas.question: The primary function of a browser is to use what?

What are private networks primarily intended to use?
Where are browsers located?

paragraphs.context: Although browsers are primarily intended to use the World Wide Web, they can also be used to access information provided by web servers in private networks or files in file systems.

allenNER.words: Although browsers are primarily intended to use the World Wide Web , they can also be used to access information provided by web servers in private networks or files in file systems .

qas.question: When was the first browser created?
Who invented the first browser?
What was Berners-Lee a director of?
What organization did Berners-Lee create?
When did Sir Tim Berners Le invent the WWW?
What was the W3C later renamed?
What does WordWideweb oversee?
What group did Nexus start?
What did Nexus invent in 1990?

paragraphs.context: The first web browser was invented in 1990 by Sir Tim Berners-Lee. Berners-Lee is the director of the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), which oversees the Web's continued development, and is also the founder of the World Wide Web Foundation. His browser was called WorldWideWeb and later renamed Nexus.

allenNER.words: The first web browser was invented in 1990 by Sir Tim Berners - Lee . Berners - Lee is the director of the World Wide Web Consortium ( W3C ) , which oversees the Web 's continued development , and is also the founder of the World Wide Web Foundation . His browser was called WorldWideWeb and later renamed Nexus .

qas.question: Who released Mosaic?
When was Mosaic released?
When Andreessen left the company he worked for, what new company did he start?
What browser did Andreessen release in 1994?
What did the World Wide Web help release in the 1990's?

plausible_answers.text: led to an explosion in web use

qas.question: What did the release of Mosaic in 1994 by NCSA lead to?
What company was started by Mosaic?
When was the NCSA Navigator released by Mosaic?
What percentage of web use did Mosaic have at its peak in 1993?

paragraphs.context: In 1993, browser software was further innovated by Marc Andreessen with the release of Mosaic, "the world's first popular browser", which made the World Wide Web system easy to use and more accessible to the average person. Andreesen's browser sparked the internet boom of the 1990s. The introduction of Mosaic in 1993 – one of the first graphical web browsers – led to an explosion in web use. Andreessen, the leader of the Mosaic team at National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), soon started his own company, named Netscape, and released the Mosaic-influenced Netscape Navigator in 1994, which quickly became the world's most popular browser, accounting for 90% of all web use at its peak (see usage share of web browsers).

allenNER.words: In 1993 , browser software was further innovated by Marc Andreessen with the release of Mosaic , " the world 's first popular browser " , which made the World Wide Web system easy to use and more accessible to the average person . Andreesen 's browser sparked the internet boom of the 1990s . The introduction of Mosaic in 1993 – one of the first graphical web browsers – led to an explosion in web use . Andreessen , the leader of the Mosaic team at National Center for Supercomputing Applications ( NCSA ) , soon started his own company , named Netscape , and released the Mosaic - influenced Netscape Navigator in 1994 , which quickly became the world 's most popular browser , accounting for 90 % of all web use at its peak ( see usage share of web browsers ) .

Bundled with Windows , Internet Explorer gained dominance in the web browser market ; Internet Explorer usage share peaked at over 95 % by 2002 .

plausible_answers.text: it has never achieved widespread use

qas.question: How has usage of the Nintendo Wii been shown over time?
How many game consoles has Nintendo sold?

paragraphs.context: Opera debuted in 1996; it has never achieved widespread use, having less than 2% browser usage share as of February 2012 according to Net Applications. Its Opera-mini version has an additive share, in April 2011 amounting to 1.1% of overall browser use, but focused on the fast-growing mobile phone web browser market, being preinstalled on over 40 million phones. It is also available on several other embedded systems, including Nintendo's Wii video game console.

allenNER.words: Opera debuted in 1996 ; it has never achieved widespread use , having less than 2 % browser usage share as of February 2012 according to Net Applications . Its Opera - mini version has an additive share , in April 2011 amounting to 1.1 % of overall browser use , but focused on the fast - growing mobile phone web browser market , being preinstalled on over 40 million phones . It is also available on several other embedded systems , including Nintendo 's Wii video game console .

qas.question: At what point did open source software gain popularity?
What software model was released in 1998?

paragraphs.context: In 1998, Netscape launched what was to become the Mozilla Foundation in an attempt to produce a competitive browser using the open source software model. That browser would eventually evolve into Firefox, which developed a respectable following while still in the beta stage of development; shortly after the release of Firefox 1.0 in late 2004, Firefox (all versions) accounted for 7% of browser use. As of August 2011, Firefox has a 28% usage share.

allenNER.words: In 1998 , Netscape launched what was to become the Mozilla Foundation in an attempt to produce a competitive browser using the open source software model . That browser would eventually evolve into Firefox , which developed a respectable following while still in the beta stage of development ; shortly after the release of Firefox 1.0 in late 2004 , Firefox ( all versions ) accounted for 7 % of browser use . As of August 2011 , Firefox has a 28 % usage share .

qas.question: Which browser is the newest to enter the field?
When was Chrome released?
As Chrome usage increases, which browser usage has continued to decrease?
When did Chrome become more used than all versions of Internet Explorer?
In what year was Internet Explorer released?
By how much did IE double its usage share?
When did Internet Explorer 8 overtake Chrome as the more popular browser?
What was IE's increase in usage percentage in August 2011?
When did the usage of IE surpass all versions of Chrome combined?

paragraphs.context: The most recent major entrant to the browser market is Chrome, first released in September 2008. Chrome's take-up has increased significantly year by year, by doubling its usage share from 8% to 16% by August 2011. This increase seems largely to be at the expense of Internet Explorer, whose share has tended to decrease from month to month. In December 2011, Chrome overtook Internet Explorer 8 as the most widely used web browser but still had lower usage than all versions of Internet Explorer combined. Chrome's user-base continued to grow and in May 2012, Chrome's usage passed the usage of all versions of Internet Explorer combined. By April 2014, Chrome's usage had hit 45%.

allenNER.words: The most recent major entrant to the browser market is Chrome , first released in September 2008 . Chrome 's take - up has increased significantly year by year , by doubling its usage share from 8 % to 16 % by August 2011 . This increase seems largely to be at the expense of Internet Explorer , whose share has tended to decrease from month to month . In December 2011 , Chrome overtook Internet Explorer 8 as the most widely used web browser but still had lower usage than all versions of Internet Explorer combined . Chrome 's user - base continued to grow and in May 2012 , Chrome 's usage passed the usage of all versions of Internet Explorer combined . By April 2014 , Chrome 's usage had hit 45 % .

plausible_answers.text: the sales of Windows to computer manufacturers and direct to users

plausible_answers.text: was part of Microsoft's overall strategy to fight threats to its quasi-monopoly platform dominance

qas.question: Why was Java available for the Mac?
In what other way did Java contribute to Windows and Microsoft application sales?

paragraphs.context: Internet Explorer, on the other hand, was bundled free with the Windows operating system (and was also downloadable free), and therefore it was funded partly by the sales of Windows to computer manufacturers and direct to users. Internet Explorer also used to be available for the Mac. It is likely that releasing IE for the Mac was part of Microsoft's overall strategy to fight threats to its quasi-monopoly platform dominance - threats such as web standards and Java - by making some web developers, or at least their managers, assume that there was "no need" to develop for anything other than Internet Explorer. In this respect, IE may have contributed to Windows and Microsoft applications sales in another way, through "lock-in" to Microsoft's browser.

allenNER.words: Internet Explorer , on the other hand , was bundled free with the Windows operating system ( and was also downloadable free ) , and therefore it was funded partly by the sales of Windows to computer manufacturers and direct to users . Internet Explorer also used to be available for the Mac . It is likely that releasing IE for the Mac was part of Microsoft 's overall strategy to fight threats to its quasi - monopoly platform dominance - threats such as web standards and Java - by making some web developers , or at least their managers , assume that there was " no need " to develop for anything other than Internet Explorer . In this respect , IE may have contributed to Windows and Microsoft applications sales in another way , through " lock - in " to Microsoft 's browser .

Microsoft Corp v Commission

allenNER.words: In January 2009 , the European Commission announced it would investigate the bundling of Internet Explorer with Windows operating systems from Microsoft , saying " Microsoft 's tying of Internet Explorer to the Windows operating system harms competition between web browsers , undermines product innovation and ultimately reduces consumer choice . " Microsoft Corp v Commission

qas.question: Which company pays Firefox to make their search engine the default on their browser?
What other browser has Google as the default search engine?
The increased revenue funds what, in addition to Google?
Why do web browsers pay search engine companies?

plausible_answers.text: to make Google Search the default search engine

qas.question: Why does Mozilla pay Google?
What lets Google not charge users for using Chrome?

plausible_answers.text: Users searching for websites or items on the Internet would be led to Google's search results page

qas.question: What increases ad revenue for Firefox?
What funds development at Mozilla?

paragraphs.context: Today, most commercial web browsers are paid by search engine companies to make their engine default, or to include them as another option. For example, Google pays Mozilla, the maker of Firefox, to make Google Search the default search engine in Firefox. Mozilla makes enough money from this deal that it does not need to charge users for Firefox. In addition, Google Search is also (as one would expect) the default search engine in Google Chrome. Users searching for websites or items on the Internet would be led to Google's search results page, increasing ad revenue and which funds development at Google and of Google Chrome.

allenNER.words: Today , most commercial web browsers are paid by search engine companies to make their engine default , or to include them as another option . For example , Google pays Mozilla , the maker of Firefox , to make Google Search the default search engine in Firefox . Mozilla makes enough money from this deal that it does not need to charge users for Firefox . In addition , Google Search is also ( as one would expect ) the default search engine in Google Chrome . Users searching for websites or items on the Internet would be led to Google 's search results page , increasing ad revenue and which funds development at Google and of Google Chrome .

paragraphs.context: The primary purpose of a web browser is to bring information resources to the user ("retrieval" or "fetching"), allowing them to view the information ("display", "rendering"), and then access other information ("navigation", "following links").

allenNER.words: The primary purpose of a web browser is to bring information resources to the user ( " retrieval " or " fetching " ) , allowing them to view the information ( " display " , " rendering " ) , and then access other information ( " navigation " , " following links " ) .

qas.question: What does URL stand for?
What is the determining factor in how a URL will be interpreted?
What does http stand for?
What does ftp stand for?

plausible_answers.text: how the URL will be interpreted

qas.question: What does the prefix of the default newsgroup reader determine?
What does the most common form of local file start with?

plausible_answers.text: a resource to be retrieved over the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP)

qas.question: What does a common browser identify?

plausible_answers.text: often handed off to another application entirely

qas.question: What happens to newsgroup readers the web browser can't handle directly?
Where are ftp's passed on to?

paragraphs.context: This process begins when the user inputs a Uniform Resource Locator (URL), for example http://en.wikipedia.org/, into the browser. The prefix of the URL, the Uniform Resource Identifier or URI, determines how the URL will be interpreted. The most commonly used kind of URI starts with http: and identifies a resource to be retrieved over the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP). Many browsers also support a variety of other prefixes, such as https: for HTTPS, ftp: for the File Transfer Protocol, and file: for local files. Prefixes that the web browser cannot directly handle are often handed off to another application entirely. For example, mailto: URIs are usually passed to the user's default e-mail application, and news: URIs are passed to the user's default newsgroup reader.

allenNER.words: This process begins when the user inputs a Uniform Resource Locator ( URL ) , for example http://en.wikipedia.org/ , into the browser . The prefix of the URL , the Uniform Resource Identifier or URI , determines how the URL will be interpreted . The most commonly used kind of URI starts with http : and identifies a resource to be retrieved over the Hypertext Transfer Protocol ( HTTP ) . Many browsers also support a variety of other prefixes , such as https : for HTTPS , ftp : for the File Transfer Protocol , and file : for local files . Prefixes that the web browser can not directly handle are often handed off to another application entirely . For example , mailto : URIs are usually passed to the user 's default e - mail application , and news : URIs are passed to the user 's default newsgroup reader .

qas.question: What is it called when content is changed from markup to an interactive document?
Browsers typically have plug-ins to support what?
Browsers have you save to disk so they can support what?
What is it called when resources are changed from being unsupported to being downloaded?
What files can be displayed when a file is unsupported?
What unsupported content can resources display that is part of a webpage?

plausible_answers.text: passed to the browser's layout engine to be transformed from markup to an interactive document

qas.question: What process happens to plug-ins saved to disk?

paragraphs.context: In the case of http, https, file, and others, once the resource has been retrieved the web browser will display it. HTML and associated content (image files, formatting information such as CSS, etc.) is passed to the browser's layout engine to be transformed from markup to an interactive document, a process known as "rendering". Aside from HTML, web browsers can generally display any kind of content that can be part of a web page. Most browsers can display images, audio, video, and XML files, and often have plug-ins to support Flash applications and Java applets. Upon encountering a file of an unsupported type or a file that is set up to be downloaded rather than displayed, the browser prompts the user to save the file to disk.

allenNER.words: In the case of http , https , file , and others , once the resource has been retrieved the web browser will display it . HTML and associated content ( image files , formatting information such as CSS , etc . ) is passed to the browser 's layout engine to be transformed from markup to an interactive document , a process known as " rendering " . Aside from HTML , web browsers can generally display any kind of content that can be part of a web page . Most browsers can display images , audio , video , and XML files , and often have plug - ins to support Flash applications and Java applets . Upon encountering a file of an unsupported type or a file that is set up to be downloaded rather than displayed , the browser prompts the user to save the file to disk .

plausible_answers.text: the browser navigates to the resource indicated by the link's target URI

qas.question: What happens when a user can't find information?

paragraphs.context: Information resources may contain hyperlinks to other information resources. Each link contains the URI of a resource to go to. When a link is clicked, the browser navigates to the resource indicated by the link's target URI, and the process of bringing content to the user begins again.

allenNER.words: Information resources may contain hyperlinks to other information resources . Each link contains the URI of a resource to go to . When a link is clicked , the browser navigates to the resource indicated by the link 's target URI , and the process of bringing content to the user begins again .

qas.question: What does e-mail also support?

paragraphs.context: Available web browsers range in features from minimal, text-based user interfaces with bare-bones support for HTML to rich user interfaces supporting a wide variety of file formats and protocols. Browsers which include additional components to support e-mail, Usenet news, and Internet Relay Chat (IRC), are sometimes referred to as "Internet suites" rather than merely "web browsers".

allenNER.words: Available web browsers range in features from minimal , text - based user interfaces with bare - bones support for HTML to rich user interfaces supporting a wide variety of file formats and protocols . Browsers which include additional components to support e - mail , Usenet news , and Internet Relay Chat ( IRC ) , are sometimes referred to as " Internet suites " rather than merely " web browsers " .

Major browsers also include pop-up blockers to prevent unwanted windows from "popping up" without the user's consent.

allenNER.words: All major web browsers allow the user to open multiple information resources at the same time , either in different browser windows or in different tabs of the same window . Major browsers also include pop - up blockers to prevent unwanted windows from " popping up " without the user 's consent .

qas.question: What kind of web pages are included in IE?

paragraphs.context: Most web browsers can display a list of web pages that the user has bookmarked so that the user can quickly return to them. Bookmarks are also called "Favorites" in Internet Explorer. In addition, all major web browsers have some form of built-in web feed aggregator. In Firefox, web feeds are formatted as "live bookmarks" and behave like a folder of bookmarks corresponding to recent entries in the feed. In Opera, a more traditional feed reader is included which stores and displays the contents of the feed.

allenNER.words: Most web browsers can display a list of web pages that the user has bookmarked so that the user can quickly return to them . Bookmarks are also called " Favorites " in Internet Explorer . In addition , all major web browsers have some form of built - in web feed aggregator . In Firefox , web feeds are formatted as " live bookmarks " and behave like a folder of bookmarks corresponding to recent entries in the feed . In Opera , a more traditional feed reader is included which stores and displays the contents of the feed .

qas.question: What did the rapid development of modern web browsers lead to?

plausible_answers.text: a combination of standards-based and de facto HTML and XHTML

qas.question: What are two things that a simple HTML version supports?

paragraphs.context: Early web browsers supported only a very simple version of HTML. The rapid development of proprietary web browsers led to the development of non-standard dialects of HTML, leading to problems with interoperability. Modern web browsers support a combination of standards-based and de facto HTML and XHTML, which should be rendered in the same way by all browsers.

allenNER.words: Early web browsers supported only a very simple version of HTML . The rapid development of proprietary web browsers led to the development of non - standard dialects of HTML , leading to problems with interoperability . Modern web browsers support a combination of standards - based and de facto HTML and XHTML , which should be rendered in the same way by all browsers .

qas.question: What parts of a layout engine make up a data persistence component?

paragraphs.context: Web browsers consist of a user interface, layout engine, rendering engine, JavaScript interpreter, UI backend, networking component and data persistence component. These components achieve different functionalities of a web browser and together provide all capabilities of a web browser.

allenNER.words: Web browsers consist of a user interface , layout engine , rendering engine , JavaScript interpreter , UI backend , networking component and data persistence component . These components achieve different functionalities of a web browser and together provide all capabilities of a web browser .
